context.text: Spectrally precoded orthogonal frequency-division multiplexing (SP-OFDM) with a rectangular pulse shape is a recently developed signaling format that can provide very small spectral sidelobes and thus very high spectral efficiency, while allowing for efficient implementation by discrete Fourier transform and the insertion of guard intervals to counteract channel dispersion [1]–[4].

The key idea is to introduce correlation among data symbols in the frequency domain with a fixed precoder matrix in a way that the power spectrum of the SP-OFDM signal exhibits very small sidelobes, which decay asymptotically as \$f^{-2J-2}\$, with \$J\$ an integer-valued design parameter and \$f\$ being the frequency in hertz [1]–[4].
General constraints on the precoding matrix have been derived in [1] to ensure the desirable fast sidelobe-decaying property.
Several spectral precoders have also been proposed in [1]–[4] for rectangularly-pulsed SP-OFDM formats with zero padding (SP-ZP-OFDM) or cyclic prefix (SP-CP-OFDM).
Although spectrally efficient, the spectral precoding techniques in [1]–[4] were developed exclusively for OFDM with independent and identically distributed (iid) and zero-mean input data.
In these systems, the input data to OFDM modulation are not independent in general and whether the existing spectral precoding techniques in [1]–[4] are applicable is not yet known.
As an addendum to [1], this letter investigates the asymptotic spectral behavior of the SP-OFDM signal for the case where the input to SP-OFDM modulation has arbitrary statistics.

By expanding the baseband equivalent power spectral density (PSD) of the SP-OFDM signal as an infinite series in \$f^{-1}\$ by using the technique of repeated integration by parts in [7], we show that the fast sidelobe-decaying constraints on the precoder matrix and the accompanied propositions previously proposed in [1]–[4] for SP-ZP-OFDM and SP-CP-OFDM signals with iid and zero-mean data are applicable to SP-ZP-OFDM and SP-CP-OFDM signals with arbitrary input statistics.

Thus, all previously-designed spectral precoders in [1]–[4] can be used to precode the SP-ZP-OFDM and SP-CP-OFDM signals with arbitrary input statistics and provide extremely small sidelobes decaying asymptotically as \$f^{-2J-2}\$.
For example, the PSD of uncoded OFDM with iid and zero-mean input data provides large sidelobes decaying asymptotically as \$f^{-2}\$ [1]–[4].
Constraint 1 is exactly the same as Constraint 1 in [1] which holds for SP-ZP-OFDM with iid and zero-mean data.
Therefore, all previously designed spectral precoders for SP-ZP-OFDM in [1]–[3] can be used to provide small spectral sidelobes for SP-ZP-OFDM with arbitrary input statistics.
Constraints 2a and 2b are exactly the same as Constraints 2a and 2b in [1] which hold for SP-CP-OFDM with iid and zero-mean data and \$T_{g}=2^{-I}T_{d}\$ for \$I \in {\cal Z}_{\log_{2}N-1}^{+}\$.

Therefore, all previously designed spectral precoders for SP-CP-OFDM in [1]–[4] can be used to provide small spectral sidelobes for SP-CP-OFDM with \$T_{g}=2^{-I}T_{d}\$ for \$I\in {\cal Z}_{\log_{2}N-1}^{+}\$ and arbitrary input statistics.

It is shown that all constraints and spectral precoders previously developed in [1]–[4] for SP-ZP-OFDM and SP-CP-OFDM signals with iid and zero-mean data ensure the desirable fast sidelobe decaying property for SP-ZP-OFDM and SP-CP-OFDM signals with arbitrary input statistics.

Here the secondary term is aimed to reduce the switching frequency in a current control of a NPC converter application [26].
